reviewText: I was gonna buy this dvd a few months back but decided not to because of the picture on the dvd cover. It just looked lame. Well i guess what they say, you cant' judge a book by its cover" is pretty darn accurate! :)The concert started out slow...I didn't like that. so i gave a 4 star.hoochie coochie man....what is so special abotu this damn song????? it's just an old standard blues rift. this is probably the only song i would never listen to twice. it's just BORING.layla was really fun to listen to though.the rythm guitar guy.....he's useless. lol. you can't even hear him. he doesn't really do any solos or anything significant. what a waste of space. the keyboard guy comes in and does the solo for layla...and the rythm guy just stands there and pluck away with his unplugged ugly guitar.bass player is truely talented.drummer.....give the old guy his props. from his face expression, it seem like he was about to fall down from being exhausted, but he never even skipped a beat.eric can talk for hours in front of camera, but he doesnt' talk much on stage. he uses his music to communicate instead. he has no personality on stage when he's not playing his guitar.where are the ladies back up vocals????dvd was worth the money. wish if i had bought it when i first saw it. whoever design the dvd front cover art needs to be fired!

reviewText: This is a great concert, despite the lack of a powerhouse sideman guitarist (such as Derek Trucks or Doyle Bramhall II as in subsequent tours). Having two keyboardists was a novel concept, and in fact, the roles played by keyboardists David Sanchez and Billy Preston (a star in his own right, of course) complement each other very well. In fact, the BEST part of this whole concert is Billy Preston's keyboard solo in "Have You Ever Loved A Woman"! I have NEVER seen such a display of dynamics and showmanship from a Hammond B3 player EVER, before or since! The way he started out really quiet, with those whispery runs and then BAM! into the next chorus, he churns out these powerful chords with that B3 and Leslie cabinet just screaming like crazy! The fact that he even gets up off his stool adds a humorous touch of showmanship. My respect for the power and capabilities of a B3 organ playing the blues multiplied several times after watching his solo! The young David Sanchez had just preceded Preston's solo with an impressive display of piano chops, but it was clear that Preston was intent of not letting that upstart upstage him! :-)OK, back to Clapton (after all, it is HIS concert)...his singing was superb, his playing was heartfelt, it's clear after watching this performance that he wasn't ready to hang up his axe anytime soon! His guitar playing is overall much more relaxed than in the old days of Cream, of course, perhaps barring some blistering runs here and there, but his feeling and passion is still there as much as ever...HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!
summary: "Have You Ever Loved A Woman" is worth the price of the whole DVD!

reviewText: This show recorded at the Staples Center in Los Angeles cptured Eric Clapton at his musical peak during the 1999 tour in support of Reptile. The concert features one of the best bands Clapton ever assembled. It includes Billy Preston and David Sancious on keyboards and long time band members Nathan East (bass), Steve Gadd (drums) and Andy Fairweather Low (guitar).The set was extremely laid back and included music from throughout Clapton's thirty plus years of recording experience. Highlights include an acoustic opening with Key to the Highway and Bell Bottom Blues as well as the jazz flavored Reptile. A bluesy middle features She's Gone, River of Tears, and Hootchie Cootchie Man. The set ends with the classics Layla and Sunshine of Your Love.If you're a Clapton fan check it out.

reviewText: I really like most of the performances on this DVD but it is no match for Cream at the Royal Albert Hall or Clapton Live at Hyde Park.  There are some stand out performances from EC and the band such as on "Badge," "River of Tears," and especially "Layla."  EC plays some inspiring guitar work on "Layla." "Layla" is actually the one performance on this DVD that is better than how it is performed on Live at Hyde Park.  Other performances that are very good on this DVD are "Change The World," "Bell Bottom Blues," "Tears In Heaven," "Over The Rainbow," and Billy Preston's "Will It Go Round In Circles."  I felt in some places such as "Have Your Ever Loved A Woman," Clapton should have played a guitar solo instead of the keyboardists playing a solo.  For this concert, I think EC was a little upstaged by Preston and David Sancious (the keyboardists).  Also, there are some songs for which EC gets less camera time than Preston and Sancious.  However, with the exception of "Cocaine" and "Wonderful Tonight," the camera stays on the band more than the audience.  There are some very silly audience shots during those two songs that I feel are inappropriate and unnecessary.  Thank goodness though that the DVD does not include as many audience shots as The Police and Paul McCartney DVDs.  One More Car, One More Rider is a very good DVD with an excellent set list, but fans should buy Live at Hyde Park and the Cream RAH DVDs first.  However, this DVD does include some gems and is worth having in your collection.  How is Clapton "Live At Montreaux?"  Has anyone seen that one?
summary: Very good but could have been a little bit better

reviewText: For too long I have tried to find a concert album/DVD of Eric Clapton that did him justice.  Quite frankly, after five or six, going back to the 60's, I was fixing to hang-it-up. Infact, I had stopped looking several years ago, and it was only when I was looking for something else that I stumbled across this gem.  With a little old (Layla, Cocaine, Sunshine of Your Love), new (Reptile), some ballads (Tears in Heaven), and standards (Hoochie Coochie Man), this DVD is a great collection of his best work.  What's really amazing is that the sounds are so clear, so concise, it's what a concert DVD should be like.Plus, you get a surprise near the end when Billie Preston sings and dances to "Will it Go Round in Circles."  If you buy this and you are disappointed, I'd start questioning whether you really liked Clapton, or just liked saying you liked Clapton.

reviewText: This is the best sounding live concert DVD I have ever heard.  The DTS mix is spot on.  I don't think it could have been done better except for boosting the volume on the drums slightly.  Incredible.  Great show put on by Eric and the boys.  A little, unplugged, a little blues, a little rock and roll and a lot of Eric.  I deducted one star for the spotty video quality here and there.  Some cameras and angles are always in focus with the right light level, others are sometimes out of focus and a tad grainy.  Still probably the best I have yet seen on DVD.  If this is ever broadcast in HD and done correctly (not on FOX) it will be spectacular.  480p does not do it justice.

reviewText: ERIC CLAPTON-ONE MORE CAR, ONE MORE RIDER (DVD): Ol' Slowhand has more concert DVDs out there than your average guitar God, and ONE MORE CAR ONE MORE RIDER's tasty roundup of blooze, rock, and pop is one of his better efforts. Backed by longtime band stalwarts Nathan East on bass and guitarist Andy Fairweather Low, with organ sideman-to-the-stars Billy Preston thrown in for ultra good measure, EC pulls out several notable stops. He trots out the timeless Muddy Waters romp HOOCHIE COOCHIE MAN, songwriter J. J. Cale's ode to excess COCAINE, and a couple of Cream and Derek and the Dominos favorites. Thankfully, LAYLA is rendered in its original classic rock manner, not as a disembowled UNPLUGGED gimmick. A pity Cale's equally outstanding AFTER MIDNIGHT or the seldom utilized six string showpiece LET IT RAIN couldn't have been squeezed in someplace, but at least musical maestro Preston gets to show his chops (not to mention some funky dance steps) on his classic WILL IT GO ROUND IN CIRCLES, a crowd pleasing encore. Clapton may have mellowed a bit with age, but his vocal and axe abilities have gone largely undiminished; to paraphrase his own overplayed wedding song staple, he was wonderful that night.RATING: FOUR RIFFS

reviewText: Summer 2001, Staples Center, Los Angeles,CA:  a sultry summer treat featuring the incomparable Eric Clapton and friends.  His on stage ensemble featured not only two of his long-term bandmates (guitarist Andy Featherweather Low and percussionist Steven Gadd) but legendary bassist Nathan East and the greatest Hammond organ player since Booker T., Billy Preston!  And the always imaginative keyboardist Greg Phillinganes..........Mr Clapton, as expected, delivers another unforgettable performance blending his acoustical guitar hits as well as a mix of his signature Fender favorites with the searing, pitch-perfect riffs he still inspires novice guitar enthusiasts with today.  The music is delightful, easy listening and thoroughly enjoyable but this concert has a sweet surprise......an incredible, electric show-stealing performance by the late, great Billy Preston (God rest HIS soul)!!!  Still the dynamic and soulful showman he had always been, burning up the ivory in a fist pounding finger clawing exhibition of pure musical joy and wild vocals inciting audience members to join the party! The concert closes with perhaps one of the most inspired renditions of the 1939 Oscar winning song "Somewhere Over the Rainbow" sung by Eric Clapton who, in his most bluesy and heartfelt style introduces (lovingly) each bandmember as a master chef divulges the secret ingredients of a savory, spicy stew that we cannot ever get enough of.

reviewText: Man I love this DVD...I've had it since it came out..this is one of my all time favorite Music DVD's..along with the Eagles. First off the quality of this DVD is stunning, The Picture is perfect even with the lights down low, and the sound and mix are incredible especially the DTS setting versus the Dolby Digital setting. The bass, drums and guitar sound like there right in your living room. and the set list is superb, Eric rips it up on the second half part of the show ( first half is an acoustic set ).If you love Clapton and love electric blues then this is a "MUST HAVE" in your collection.
summary: Slowhand Shows us how to play with Feeling!

reviewText: He starts the concert with an accoustic guitar version of "Key To The Highway Me". His voice is in fine form and the guitar is naturally great. Then the band join him for a gentle Jazz influenced instrumental from Reptile and its here you realise that this going to be something special.This is his regular touring band from that time i.e. Andy Fairweather-Low, Nathan East and Steve Gadd, but also David Sancious on keyboards and best of all Billy preston on Hammond Organ and vocals.The concert is marvellous, and its my favourite Clapton DVD. Full of great performances - you won't be disappointed with this. A special mention must go to the late Billy Preston, the 5th Beatle. His performance of "Will it go round in circles?" (his own song) is so infectious. He clearly loved being in the spotlight and its a great shame that this is probably one of his last recorded performances.This is in widescreen with stereo, 5.1 dolby digital, and DTS audio options.

When the main program is this good, you don't need anything else.Highlights: "My Father's Eyes", "Change the World", "Wonderful Tonight".  Weirdest song choice, "Over the Rainbow", but it works well and while it's tough to top Judy's version this one is worthy.I have great admiration for Mr. Clapton and the musicians that make up his band. reviewText: The absolute best $12 I HAVE EVER SPENT - Bar none!!!! Video quality Great, Sound Great, Clapton sounds and looks Great!!! This DVD includes one of the final performances by Billy Preston before his health declined. Nathan West, Andy Fairweather Low and Steve Gadd provide great back up on bass, guitar, vocals and drums respectively while David Sancious performs many great keyboard solos. Must check out "Have you ever loved a woman" with phenomenal keyboard performances from Dave Sancious and Billy Preston and a strong blues lick from Clapton. The performance of "Layla" is one of the best I've heard and I've heard a lot!!! Those of you with large screen tv's and surround sound will be in absolute heaven. CHECK IT OUT and ENJOY!!
summary: RIP - Billy Preston - Clapton is Remarkable

reviewText: After viewing dozens and dozens of concert DVD's, I have to say this has instantly become one of my all-time favorites.  The quality of the audio & video (and thus the viewing experience) is phenomenal.  TOP...TOP NOTCH!The DTS soundtrack is superb.  The mix of the instruments is second to none for rock & roll style music.  If you love the quality of the Diana Krall - Live in Paris DVD...then you will appreciate this one from Clapton.  Same quality presentation, different genre.  I especially love the tasteful use of crowd noise.  It isn't overpowering like most concert DVD's where you constantly want to turn the volume down at the end of each song.  This one is thoughtfully mixed providing the essential "just like being there" feeling without overpowering you with obscenely loud crowd ambience.The video is nearly as wonderful.  I love the widescreen aspect ratio.  It is the ONLY way to present a concert!  Why aren't all concert DVD's widescreen?!  With my Samsung DVD-HD931 upconverting the 460i to 720p (high definition) it looks superb.  Unlike the recent Peter Gabriel DVD that is so grainy originally that it only looks worse when upconverted.  Good colors and nice wide shots without too much panning or quick camera tricks.  Cameras focus on the musicians who are being featured during segments of each song.  Thankfully Clapton had a hand in mixing this baby!  The result is an extremely tasteful video presentation.GRAB THIS ONE FOR YOUR COLLECTION.  A real keeper...and sure to become one of your favorite demo discs.
summary: Reference Quality Concert DVD...One of the Finest!
